p.span: Consideration in Detail

The SPEAKER (15:48): In accordance with the resolution agreed to earlier, the bills will be taken as a whole. The resolution also provided for any government amendments to the bills that have been circulated to be treated as if they had been moved together, any opposition amendments to the bills that have been circulated to be treated as if they had been moved together, and any amendments that have been circulated by non-aligned members to be treated as if they had been moved together by the member proposing them. Copies of the amendments have been circulated and have been placed on the table. The question now is that the bills be agreed to.

span.span: Coronavirus Economic Response Package (Payments and Benefits) Bill 2020

p.span: (1) Clause 7, page 4 (after line 29), at the end of clause, add:

(3) Before making rules for the purposes of subsection (1) that provide for a payment or scheme to assist businesses to cover the costs of wages of their employees, the Treasurer must consider the following:
(a) the need to support essential workers and services in key sectors and regions;
(b) the need for all casual employees to access support;
(c) the consequences for employees who may be required to run down leave entitlements;
(d) the needs of charities that may experience a decline in donations but not in GST turnover;
(e) the recognition of the status of universities and schools that are ACNC-registered charities;
(f) the needs of registered NDIS providers and the disability workforce;
(g) the needs of active business participants;
(h) the need to support temporary visa holders who are unable to return home;
(i) the needs of local government employees.

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (15:49): I understand that, given the resolution, I don't need to say that I move the amendment. It's automatically taken as moved. The opposition is putting forward one amendment to the Coronavirus Economic Response Package (Payments and Benefits) Bill 2020. The way this bill has been structured is that all the power of eligibility lies outside of the parliament, and what we're effectively doing is giving the Treasurer extraordinary powers to be able to devise the scheme. This amendment accepts that that's the way that it's been structured, but the fact that it's been structured that way prevents us from going line by line and moving amendments to change the principles of eligibility. So what this amendment does to the sections of the bill that give the Treasurer the power to establish the rules is put in a demand about what he must consider. That would put in place the demand that he consider the need for all casuals to access support so that we don't have this ridiculous situation where the person who is working for pocket money gets $1,500 a fortnight and the person who's working for their livelihood gets told they're ineligible.

It would also deal with the consequences for employees who may be in a situation where they are required to run down leave entitlements. Just think of how this works. At the moment, the way it's designed, an employer has an employee running down their annual leave, and that annual leave is already credited against the balance sheet of the employer. The employer is able to receive the wage subsidy and still run down the annual leave at the full rate, which means that what the taxpayer's funding is not the worker. It's not actually a job subsidy; we're funding the balance sheet of the employer. There are some measures that have been brought to this parliament that have been upfront and that, it has been said, were being brought forward for the specific purpose of supporting business during that time, and we have backed those measures in, but we should not have a situation where something that is meant to be a wage subsidy is allowed to be rorted as a payment to the employer, not to the employee. That's what's allowed to happen during periods of leave, and it's not what this is about. If the amount is going to be forwarded to the employer during a period of leave, the employee should only be losing their entitlement to the extent that the employer is paying for them to lose their entitlement. And that may well mean that people would be able to take their leave over a much longer period of time, which would make a real difference to workers during this period.

The needs of charities that may experience a decline in donations but not in GST turnover; the recognition of the current status of ACNC registered universities and schools; the needs of NDIS providers and the disability workforce; the needs of active business participants; the need to support temporary visa holders who are unable to return home; and the needs of local government employees—these issues should be front of mind. At the moment, they don't get a look-in. The principle of this bill is that we want to keep people's relationship with their employer. It is better for them now. It will keep some businesses running that would otherwise fall over. And, at the end of this period, it will make a massive difference as to how the economy can recover. There is no economic reason for rejecting any of these principles. The only reason for rejecting these principles is a stubbornness because they weren't part of the original announcement and, therefore, the government won't shift.

A number of these measures, including the one I referred to with respect to leave, would be cost-neutral for the government but make a massive difference to people's income during this time. And there are other issues—for example, whether employers choose to not put forward all their employees. That is a risk at the moment in the way the government is intending to design this, which will create a situation where employers can try to get agreement from workers, for actions that are meant to be voluntary, by threatening not to put them forward for the JobKeeper payment.

This is an issue which can be resolved by the Treasurer, and I want to refer to that while I'm on my feet. We've all presumed that the employers who are eligible will apply and they will then put forward the names of all their employees who are eligible. The rules that were submitted yesterday don't guarantee that. The Treasurer can fix this and should fix this. Think about this: the government was aware of the risk of people being forced to take leave for double the time and at half the pay. The government has made some efforts to try and make that voluntary and to make sure that it will be voluntary. I commend the government for those discussions.

Most employers will deal with this in the right way. But under the rules at the moment, in the way the Treasurer has put them forward, on the face of it—and we've had these rules for less than a day—it will be possible for an employer to say to their workforce: 'I haven't decided which of you I'm going to put forward for the wage subsidy. Before I make that decision, who's willing to take their leave—double the time and at half the pay?' They wait till that question is answered and then choose which employees get put forward for the job subsidy. By doing it for an extended period of time, the rort that I described earlier doubles the period during which the money is going to the employer rather than to the employee.

Most employers will deal with this appropriately. Most will. But, in every case in industrial relations, we always have to set the boundaries to make sure that we have protected Australia from bad actors. At the moment, in the current design, this doesn't. It can be fixed, and for most workers it won't need to be fixed. But it is a relatively easy fix that matches what the government says it is trying to do. I appreciate that some of this is because of the rush with time, and it all goes to the reason why parliament should be sitting more often: that there will be outcomes we have not anticipated. But this is one that won't require the Treasurer to come back to the parliament if he chooses to change the rules. This amendment will demand that these issues be considered as these rules, as they are referred to in the act, are put in place.

Finally, I want to refer to conversations that have been happening with the Attorney-General. The draft of the changes to the Fair Work Act that we were provided with last night had some areas that were of significant concern. What's happened overnight is that there have been a number of further changes which have fixed some of those concerns. There is a final issue which had not been fixed, and I want to report to the House that I am satisfied about it because a particular undertaking has been given in conversations with the Attorney-General. The challenge is this: we want people to agree with their employer during this period for as much flexibility as possible so that things that would normally not happen can happen during this period so that businesses survive and people keep their jobs; it's a level of flexibility we want. There are some employment conditions where employees, once they have done something, lose the right to object to it in the future. So the fact that these rules are only temporary won't change the fact that there will have been a point in the past at which they agreed to it. We need to make sure that no employee is punished in the future for flexibility now, and that hasn't been covered in the amendments. The Attorney-General has given an undertaking that, when he puts together the form for employers to be able to use these provisions, they will have to give an undertaking that it won't be to the detriment of the employee in the future. I do believe that that covers it off.

To the extent that we've been able to deal with all the issues in front of us in an extraordinarily brief period of time, I think we have got to a good point. This amendment would put extra demands on the government in addition to what they are wanting now. But I have to say that, if we believe in the economic case for this change—and we all do—leaving so many workers behind is in no-one's interest. I commend the amendment.

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (15:59): I thank the member for his contribution on the Coronavirus Economic Response Package (Payments and Benefits) Bill 2020 and related bills. We don't agree, and won't be agreeing, to these amendments.

In relation to the member's first comments on the structure of the scheme: yes, the scheme is structured, of course, to provide a wage guarantee and to support the six million Australians who we believe are ultimately going to access the JobKeeper payments. But, importantly, it is also there to ensure that the businesses which employ them are there in six months time in order to continue to employ them. I think that looking at that structure answers some of the questions and some of the points that the member has made, particularly in relation to leave entitlements. It's a vexed and complex issue, but I think the work that has been done by the responsible minister in particular in negotiating a number of these arrangements addresses the primary concerns. But, at the same time, it's in the framework in recognition that, ultimately, in addition to supporting the employees we're also supporting the liabilities, at times, of employers to make sure that they're there in however long it takes to get through this crisis—that they are there on the other side to continue to employ them.

In relation to casuals, which the member raised: the Prime Minister made it very clear—and I think put it very well in question time—that the jobseeker scheme builds upon the earlier tranches of economic support that the government provided, most notably the jobseeker payment. Jobseeker payment recognised that there would be those who, through no fault of their own, lost their job. That's why, through the coronavirus supplement of an additional $550 a fortnight, that additional support is available to them.

The JobKeeper payment, as the Treasurer has described, is a uniquely Australian designed scheme within the broad framework of a wage subsidy. No-one was talking about this extending all the way to casuals a few weeks ago. We made it very clear that we wanted this to be as expansive as possible: a six-month payment at 70 per cent of median wages that extends to part-time and long-term casuals—and we've drawn on definitions that are well understood within industrial relations law with respect to the definition of casuals. So the JobKeeper scheme appropriately recognises that. That is wide in its remit and, for those employees or former employees who can't access JobKeeper, this just builds upon the increased safety net that this government has provided through the jobseeker payment.

In relation to charities and not-for-profits, which were mentioned by the member for Watson: again, the government has recognised the enormous contribution that charities and not-for-profits play in our country, and the some one million employees who work in that sector. We're very keen to extend this to charities and to not-for-profits. I would note that there are provisions in the bill which ensure for entities which are deductible gift recipients that donations are taken into account for the purposes of the turnover test, to make sure that those entities which rely heavily on donations are able to get access to the JobKeeper scheme for their employees because of what we expect is going to be the inevitable drop-off in donations to those types of entities.
So we have an expansive scheme and it addresses a number of the points that the member for Watson has raised, and for those reasons we don't support his amendments.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Andrews ): The question before the House is that the opposition amendment be disagreed to.

Mr BANDT (Melbourne—Leader of the Australian Greens) (16:03): I rise to speak on the Coronavirus Economic Response Package (Payments and Benefits) Bill 2020 and related bills. On behalf of the Greens, I support these amendments that are being moved by the opposition, because they go some way towards picking up some of the people who have been left behind in the government's package. Chief amongst those, and who we have been campaigning for, are casual workers. I hope the opposition might reconsider its earlier position and support some of the amendments which the Greens will move in the Senate in an attempt also to close some of the holes and fill some of the gaps that have been left in this scheme. Certainly, when that happened last time we were able to get somewhere with the government. I would hope that when it comes to looking after workers that we can potentially go even further in the Senate than some of these amendments, and make sure that people aren't left behind.

I have two questions for the minister, relating to some of the things that the minister just said and who is going to be covered by these schemes. One is with respect to groups of employees who aren't casuals but who work on repeated short-term contracts. I'm thinking particularly of people who work in the arts. There would be people who work on productions—on shows like the Melbourne Comedy Festival, which has just been cancelled—whose income will be patchy over the course of a year. They will perhaps move from production to production, from gig to gig and work for a period. It might be for a few weeks or a few months at a time. They will save up an income and then wait until they get the next job, and then go on to that. They will often do that as employees. They may not do it as casual employees—I'm not talking about casuals. It may be that they do it on a contract basis, or they do it as full-time employees on a fixed-time contract or they do it as part-time employees.

I understand the point about casuals, and I disagree with it—and we'll pursue those amendments separately. But, putting aside whether people are casuals or not, my question to the minister is that if someone has a proven history of earning income to keep themselves afloat, and they do it on a job-by-job basis—for example, in the arts industry—is it the case that if they happened to be working on, say, a production or on a contract at 1 March then they're entitled to jobseeker payment, but if for whatever reason their contract finished two days earlier then they're not now going to be entitled to jobseeker payment? And, if that's right—and we're talking about people who have been employees, as opposed to sole traders, and putting aside casuals versus noncasuals—would the minister consider an extension of the scheme to cover those people who have a proven history of earning incomes above the jobseeker level?

I would ask the minister to consider making those people entitled to the JobKeeper payment—let them register as a sole trader or however we need to to minimise the changes that need to be made to the scheme. If someone has a proven history of income earning, albeit in a patchy way, will the minister undertake to look at making the scheme available to those people, even if they weren't employed on 1 March, or if, for whatever reason, their employer determines that they're not going to pick up the scheme on 1 March?

For people who work on and off throughout the course of the year and get a decent income, but find themselves, for whatever reason, ineligible for the current JobKeeper payment, will you consider making them eligible for JobKeeper if they can demonstrate a proven history of earning income through work? That's the first question that I have for the minister.

The second question relates to the breadth of the rules and the powers that can be made under the payments and benefits bill. Can the minister confirm to the House that the power and the rules that will be made cannot be used to take away an existing entitlement or benefit that someone may have under some other act or some other scheme? In other words, if someone has an entitlement, whether it's under an industrial award, or it's a social security payment or the right to get some kind of housing payment—whatever it is, if someone has an existing right to access a benefit can the minister confirm that the payments and benefits bill does not authorise the making of rules to take away those benefits and entitlements? And, if that's not the case, can the minister say so, but give an undertaking that they won't be used in that way?

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (16:08): In relation to long-term casuals, and as I described earlier in my remarks to the member for Watson, where possible we have sought to draw on an existing understanding of those terms within our industrial relations framework. With respect to casuals, we refer to them as 'long-term', 'regular' and 'systematic', so if they've got a systematic, long-term and ongoing relationship with that employer and therefore for the purposes of our industrial relations system they are considered a casual employee of that employer—and have been for longer than 12 months, as of 1 March—then, yes, of course they will be entitled to the JobKeeper payment.

I know the member for Melbourne explicitly carved out from his question the point around sole traders. As I'm sure he understands, particularly in the arts and entertainment industry so many of the individuals involved are in that contract relationship as sole traders or, effectively, as self-employed individuals. The government has been very keen to make sure that sole traders—people who, at the end of the day, only get paid when they work—are also included in this JobKeeper scheme. Again, we've drawn on the well-understood term within our industrial relations framework of an 'ongoing and systematic relationship' between an employee and an employer for the purposes of that casual test. Again, to go to the specifics of the arts and entertainment industry, of course those independent contractors, sole traders and self-employed individuals would also qualify.
The SPEAKER: The question is that the opposition amendment be disagreed to.

body.p:
The House divided. [16:15]
(The Speaker—Hon. Tony Smith)

Question agreed to.
Bills agreed to.

p.span: Third Reading

The SPEAKER (16:17): I have received messages from His Excellency the Governor-General recommending in accordance with section 56 of the Constitution an appropriation for the purposes of the Coronavirus Economic Response Package (Payments and Benefits) Bill 2020 and the Coronavirus Economic Response Package Omnibus (Measures No. 2) Bill 2020. In accordance with the resolution agreed earlier, I will now put the question that these bills be read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bills read a third time.
BUSINESS
Leave of Absence
Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (16:19): I move:
That leave of absence be given to every Member of the House of Representatives from the determination of this sitting of the House to the date of its next sitting.
Question agreed to.

Mr VAN MANEN (Forde—Chief Government Whip) (16:19): on indulgence—Just in recognition of the unusual times that we're in and the fact that, to hold this sitting here today across this chamber, 47 of our colleagues—on this side and on the opposition benches—aren't here, as they've been paired. I'd like to just acknowledge their names for the record: the member for Bennelong, the member for McPherson, the member for Moncrieff, the member for Monash, the member for Wright, the member for Dawson, the member for Stirling, the member for Cowper, the member for Banks, the member for Dickson, the member for Leichhardt, the member for Brisbane, the member for Lyne, the member for Moore, the member for Curtin, the member for La Trobe, the member for Canning, the member for Mitchell, the member for Page, the member for Petrie, the member for Swan, the member for New England, the member for Hughes, the member for Bowman, the member for Chisholm, the member for Capricornia, the member for Maranoa, the member for Forrest, the member for Groom, the member for Hume, the member for Fairfax, the member for Flynn, the member for Barker, the member for Braddon, the member for Hinkler, the member for Durack, the member for Grey, the member for Ryan, the member for Sturt, the member for Herbert, the member for Bonner, the member for Fisher, the member for Mallee, the member for Robertson, the member for O'Connor, the member for Hasluck and the member for Longman.

I would like to thank the House and thank all the members for their assistance in being prepared to not be here to assist the House to hold these sittings today and to pass this very important legislation.

Mr HAYES (Fowler—Chief Opposition Whip) (16:21): on indulgence—I, too, would like to name all the members who are not here today from the opposition. Their nonattendance has allowed us to be here to pass necessary legislation to help in relation to the coronavirus. The opposition agreed to pair 47 government members, and, because of that, many of my colleagues were not able to be here today. As a matter of fact, as a consequence, only 21 Labor members are here in the chamber. We owe a debt of gratitude to those who showed their cooperation in allowing us to have our sitting today with the necessary social distancing that applies.

I would like to thank Ms Aly, the member for Cowan; Mr Burns, the member for Macnamara; Ms Butler, the member for Griffith; Mr Byrne, the member for Holt; Mr Champion, the member for Spence; Ms Chester, the member for Bendigo; Ms Coker, the member for Corangamite; Mr Conroy, the member for Shortland; Mr Dick, the member for Oxley; Mr Dreyfus, the member for Isaacs; Ms Elliot, the member for Richmond; Mr Fitzgibbon, the member for Hunter; Mr Georganas, the member for Adelaide; Mr Giles, the member for Scullin; Mr Gorman, the member for Perth; Mr Hill, the member for Bruce; Ms Kearney, the member for Cooper—and I also pause to acknowledge the tragic death in their family and pay my respects to her and her partner, Leigh Hubbard; Mr Kelly, the member for Eden-Monaro; Mr Keogh, the member for Burt; Mr Khalil, the member for Wills; Mr Mitchell, the member for Lyons; Dr Mulino, the member for Fraser; Ms Murphy, the member for Dunkley; Mr Neumann, the member for Blair; Ms O'Neil, the member for Hotham; Ms Owens, the member for Parramatta; Ms Payne, the member for Canberra; Mr Perrett, the member for Moreton; Mrs Phillips, the member for Gilmore; Ms Rishworth, the member for Kingston; Ms Rowland, the member for Greenway; Mr Snowdon, the member for Lingiari; Ms Swanson, the member for Paterson; Ms Templeman, the member for Macquarie; Mr Thistlethwaite, the member for Kingsford Smith; Ms Thwaites, the member for Jagajaga; Ms Vamvakinou, the member for Calwell; Mr Watts, the member for Gellibrand; Ms Wells, the member for Lilley; Mr Wilson, the member for Fremantle; and Mr Zappia, the member for Makin.

I would also like to acknowledge: we did have a reserve list of members to be in the building but not necessarily in the parliament, just in case we needed to have others to attend. So I acknowledge Ms Bird, the member for Cunningham; Dr Freelander, the member for Macarthur; Mr Husic, the member for Chifley; Mr Gosling, the member for Solomon; Ms McBride, the member for Dobell; and Mr Smith, the member for Bean. I generally thank those members for their cooperation in allowing us to sit the way we have to pass the necessary legislation to help and assist in relation to the coronavirus.
The SPEAKER: The Leader of the Greens on indulgence.

Mr BANDT (Melbourne—Leader of the Australian Greens) (16:25): on indulgence, if I may—it's not in exactly the same category, but the member for Kennedy, Mr Katter, who I spoke to beforehand, has expressed that he is also staying away to facilitate a parliament that can meet with restricted numbers. I understand that the members for Mayo and Clark may have also separately corresponded and had their correspondence tabled; they are in the same position.

The SPEAKER: I thank the Chief Government Whip, the Chief Opposition Whip and the Leader of the Greens for placing the names of all of those members on the record. It is very important that those members are recognised. I know electorate offices are very, very busy, as we know here, but I thank them for the sacrifice of agreeing not to come. Looking around the chamber, it's self-evident why they couldn't all come.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (16:26): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, I present the 11th report of the committee, Petitions and ministerial responses.

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (16:27): by leave—I present the following petitions. I acknowledge the support of the Leader of the House and the Manager of Opposition Business in allowing the presentation of petitions at this time.
Transaction Fees
10% charges
Charging people money for using a card should be banned
We therefore ask the House to investigate why business charge people for use tap a go and make ilegal to charge people for use tap a go to buy or use products at there business
From 2 citizens (EN1130)
Religious Beliefs
who believes the Earth is 6000 years old
Our parliament is responsible for running this country and that involves a lot of scientific processes and thinking to be applied in the best possible manner.

Some people believe God created the earth 6000 years ago meaning a lot of our sciences are a nonsense to their religion. If those people are also MPs does their belief system allow them to act in the best way to run this country?
Every person has the right to their own beliefs, but those beliefs should not endanger others or lessen an MPs efficiency in parliament.
We therefore ask the House to create a list of MPs who believe the Earth was created by God 6000 years ago.
From 2 citizens (EN1206)
Banking and Financial Services
Fees
This is a matter in which house can act for the good of the citizens

We therefore ask the House to examine why banks and other organizations charge to withdrawl money over counter recently i withdrew $30 over counter and the bank charged $3 at atm you get hit $2,50 each action over a period of time you loose 1000s to banks in fees . You are forced to use banks for pays and other stuff . You pay interest yet the fees this should be examined as banks double dipping on fees in every step . On the other end when you purchase a item from a shop example food or cloths you get charged a fee to cover the fee the banks charge shops is this really fair system to the consumer. We their for ask the government to ban charging excess fees to australians . If banks want supply atm for convenience of people they should waive fee. They supply atm and cashless cards to cut workforce but fees are huge . Its time fees are examined on atm. banks a shops and other business low wage earners cannot sustain this system they cant get ahead with this system is it really fair to pass the fees through to consumer its double dipping big time . Banks are the only winner in it .you get paid a wage for a job and when you purchase a item the bank gets a bite at every step
From 4 citizens (EN1207)
Telecommunications
Make Sky News Australia available on Free-To-Air TV Australia wide

Due to the unbalanced and biased reporting and programming of the ABC, we hereby request that Sky News be given access to broadcast on the Free To Air terrestrial television network so it can be viewed by all Australians, not just those in rural areas. Australians deserve a full choice of political news coverage.

We therefore ask the House to enact any necessary legislation to grant Sky News permission to broadcast on the FTA network, and also grant Sky News a digital broadcast licence free of charge to offset any potential loss of revenue.
From 2 citizens (EN1210)
Donations to Political Parties
Abolish Political Donations

Political donations diminish the political rights of Australian citizens and give corporate interests and wealthy individuals undue influence over parties and members of parliament. This increasingly powerful and disproportionate leverage creates outcomes and policy that do not benefit Australian citizens but instead erodes their sovereignty.

According to the Australian Electoral Commission, "Democracy comes from the Greek words demos meaning 'the people' and kratos meaning 'power'. Effectively, the word 'democracy' means 'people power' – the right of people to make decisions on how they are governed." Democracy is a system of government in which the power is vested in the people, however the Australian parliament has passed laws that shield the nature of political funding. The delay in reporting political donations means that the parties will report donations from the 2019 election in February 2020, eight months after voting day.

This lack of transparency allows political parties to pitch and implement favourable policy to major donors without scrutiny from the media and the Australian public. The Australian government adopts the 'If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear' stance regarding the privacy and rights of Australian citizens. It is time that they were held to the same standard.

We therefore ask the House to pass a law enforcing the immediate disclosure of all political donations and to immediately abolish direct donations to MPs and parties. Under this law, all future political donations must be made to the Australian Electoral Commission and distributed to parties and independents equally.
From 138 citizens (EN1211)
Mental Health
Use of Psychotropic drug on Australian children, electric shock treatment

I am requesting the house to ban the use of psychotropic drugs treatments and other treatments such as electric shock treatment to treat children in Australia, in view of the implementation of a compulsory screening for mental illness in Australian children from 0-3.
We therefore ask the House to ban these practices and implement a complementary strategy for children who are experiencing neurological illness and testing.

In view of the 1000's of children that are at risk within our community of becoming harmed for life and their social freedoms being stolen through the use of these dangerous and ineffective treatments.
From 4 citizens (EN1212)
Wolf, Dr Naomi
Correct Hansard on Dr Naomi Wolf

In his first speech to Parliament in 2013, Angus Taylor falsely implied that feminist author and academic Dr Naomi Wolf was part of a "war on Christmas" at Oxford University during his time there. He stated: "It was 1991, and a young Naomi Wolf lived a couple of doors down the corridor. Several graduate students... decided we should abandon the Christmas tree..."

That this inference may be taken as fact is evidenced by a 2014 profile of Mr Taylor in the AFR, which includes this sentence: "When [Wolf] proposed banning the traditional Christmas tree, Taylor, a Christian, led a successful counter rebellion." Despite this assertion being demonstrably false, neither Mr Taylor nor the AFR have ever issued a correction.

Naomi Wolf completed her studies at Oxford in 1988, and by 1991 was resident in New York, having just published her first book. She wishes the Parliament and people of Australia to know that she has never objected to the celebration of Christmas, at Oxford or anywhere else.

We, the petitioners, as Australian citizens, make this request on behalf of Dr Wolf, because the evidence that Mr Taylor's claim is false is incontrovertible, and we find Dr Wolf's desire to clear her name to be legitimate and reasonable.

We therefore ask the House to clarify in the Hansard record that, contrary to Mr Taylor's assertions, Naomi Wolf has never been part of any so-called "war on Christmas" and was not at Oxford during his time there.
From 8 citizens (EN1213)
Taxation
Tax exemption for our firefighters this year

Due to the horrendous fire conditions the firefighters have endured I believe they should be exempt from tax this year. Our defense personnel don't have to pay tax on their salary and allowances while they are deployed and I believe firefighters this year should receive the same benefits. Like our defense personnel protecting our country, our firefighters too are defending our country against the most powerful force of all (mother nature). All Australians should give thanks to them for the outstanding work they have done and exemption from tax is a great way to show our appreciation.
We therefore ask the House to Tax-exempt any firefighter who has actively fought against the fires this financial year.
From 5 citizens (EN1214)

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications

p.span: Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications
Put "Arts" back in the name of the department

The abolition of the Department of Communication and the Arts through the creation of the new mega-department, the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications, renders the arts invisible at the top tier of decision-making. This decision sends a strong signal that Australia does not value the arts. The sacking of the secretary of the Department of Communications and the Arts is a further indication that the arts are being undervalued and suppressed. To quote Esther Anatolitis: "Arts and culture is a $111.7bn industry. It employs more people than mining, IT or essential services. It is also among the fastest-growing. Policies that propel the arts propel the entire economy, with flow-on effects in education and health as well as infrastructure, and urban and regional development. The places where we make and experience art are the heart and soul of every place, every town, every city – and every home."
We therefore ask the House to pass legislation which:
- Requires the word "Arts" to be reinstated to the title of the department to which it belongs, to ensure the arts are given due prominence and recognition
- Re-employs the senior public servant to head the Department of Arts within the new mega-department
- Expresses the House's support of the arts and all that the sector brings to the country and humanity generally
- Affirms the House's commitment to always fund the arts properly and recognises the significant contribution the arts make to Australia's economy
From 2 citizens (EN1215)
Gambling
Enact a Complete Blanket Ban on Sports-Betting and Gambling Advertisments

Because of the prevalence of sports-betting (such as SportsBet and Ladbrokes) and other gambling advertisements (such as OzLotto and Instant Scratch-It) on Australian media, children and adults are beginning to form positive associations of gambling, including the use of betting terminology within schoolyards and playgrounds. This is especially concerning due to the massive amounts of money that are lost yearly to gambling and betting. In 2014, $21 billion dollars were lost to gambling, an average of $1300 per person.

In the same way that the advertising of cigarettes was completely banned and packaging was made plain in order to reduce the likelihood of positive association with such substances, the complete banning of sport-betting and gambling advertisements (including scratch-cards and lotteries) will reduce the likelihood of children and adults being suffering as a result of gambling addictions. Which will reduce the amount of money lost and lives ruined from casinos, sports-betting and other gambling.

The current advertising laws on gambling are not strong enough, and a blanket ban on all gambling advertisements is the only option that will be sufficient to stop the fostering of gambling addictions and positive association within children and adults.

We therefore ask the House to enact a complete and total ban on all sports-betting and gambling (including scratch-cards and lotteries) advertisements in Australia, whether on the television, radio or online without exception.
From 8 citizens (EN1217)
Arts
Ensure a Future for Australian Arts

We are asking the House to ensure that we do not lose a dedicated department for the Arts in Australia. Our arts culture greatly benefits the economy, by not only creating jobs for many Australians every year, but also encourages tourism throughout out nation.

A dedicated Federal Department for the Arts also allows creatives of Australia to shape our cultural identity, which in turn positively reflects our nation on an international stage. From Musicians and Actors, to Artists and Authors, the arts is as much of an important part of our culture as any sporting team.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that there is a federal department with a MAJOR focus on the Arts; provide a clear understanding of the Government's future plans for the Arts in Australia; ensure that there is more funding and less cuts, as well as more resources given to our arts community.
From 2 citizens (EN1218)
Human Rights
Enactment of Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability law substantially

Australian Citizens have not only seen increasing foreign influences in our home land but also our financial institutes assisting the financing of gross Human Rights violation activities overseas in recent years.

None of these could have happened if the assets, immigration of certain foreign nations, and transactions, that exhibit strong association with these activities are subject to the sanctions of our Government. When these Human Rights gross violation actors come to Australia they bring their influence and connections with them and in turn it gives rise to stronger foreign influences.

Other civilised nations sharing the similar values with us (e.g. UK, US, Canada, Japan, Netherlands) have enacted or have an agenda to enacted legislation in one form or another to sanction the actors of gross Human Rights violation and corruption globally. These measures do not only ensure their nations will not be used in any ways be the safe haven of these actors, but also provide deterrence for these violations.

Australia is one of the world most popular safe places for the wealthy people to deposit their wealth and enjoy their retirement. Australia needs Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability law (substantially similar to the US version) to preserve our core values, and more importantly to stay true to the commitment to Human Rights that we rightfully committed to since 1972.
We therefore ask the House to enact Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability law substantially similar to US version.
From 2230 citizens (EN1220)
Prime Minister
Vote of no confidence against Prime Minster Scott Morrison

The Australian people would like a motion of no confidence passed against the current Australian Prime Minister, Scott Morrison due to his neglect and failure to carry out his obligation to serve and protect the best interests of the Australian people, and the land in which they inhabit.
We therefore ask the House to put forward a motion of no confidence against the current Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison as to have the voice and opinion of the people of Australia heard.
From 12 citizens (EN1222)
Defence Facilities
Cancel the disposal by sale of Leewuin Barracks, Western Australia
Prevent the further loss of military heritage in Western Australia
Continue association of ADF Cadet units with the facility
Veterans organisations potential use of facilities including emergency accommodation for homeless veterans, veterans support services etc
The use of the facility in times of emergency for housing of displaced persons
Use of facilities grounds for community events
Maintain memorials on site

We therefore ask the House to respectfully review the proposed disposal of Leeuwin Barracks, potentially to overseas investors and that the barracks and its surrounding facilities be retained and that consideration in lieu of sale, a peppercorn lease to Veterans Groups be considered

The public benefit of the use of Leeuwin Barracks by veteran organisations for veteran and community use would maintain the long historical link between the Defence Force and the local community for future generations. The consolidation of services for the Veteran community of Western Australia at Leeuwin Barracks, would provide long term benefits to veterans, their families and local business.

Consideration should also be given, in that Leeuwin Barracks, being the only facility within Western Australia with direct links to both the Royal Australian Navy and the Australian Army while also providing emergency shelter for East Timorese civilians evacuated during the East Timor conflict of independence.
From 31 citizens (EN1223)
Religious Freedom
We need freedom from Religion

Part V of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act "Powers of the Parliament" does not provide for power to legislate on matters of religion. In fact, Section 116 "Commonwealth not to legislate in respect of religion" prohibits our Government from making laws that establish religion, that impose religious observance or that prohibit free exercise of religion. The specific prescriptions outlined in the current Freedom of Religion Bill put by our Parliament therefore are inconsistent with the powers available to it under our Constitution.

We therefore ask the House to withdraw the current Freedom of Religion Bill. Freedom from religion must be established if we are to remain a secular State and prevent any religion from unduly being at the basis of our laws.
From 11 citizens (EN1224)
Water
Give them water!

We are well aware of the horrific drought ruining multiple areas of Australia and the affect it is having on our Farmers and their livelihoods, not to mention the millions of animals that have lost their lives to this drought. We CAN and MUST do something about it!

We therefore ask the House to open and start running the Desalination Plant located in Wonthaggi, Victoria to its full potential and give our farmers the water they so desperately need. This not only creates thousands of jobs for workers, truck drivers and others alike but we can give our struggling Aussies a fighting chance!
From 2 citizens (EN1225)
Forestry
Develop policy for reforestation of unproductive land

A number of scientist have announced that planting trees, reforestation, on a global scale is the most economical action that can be taken to reduce CO2 in the atmosphere in order to reduce temperature increase and therefore climate change.

Scientists have announced that, for Australia, planting trees in the tropical east coast region has the potential to provide the greatest impact. However, there are many, many hectares of cleared land, which is not productive farming land, which could be reforested. Planting trees on a large scale would have the added benefits of creating employment, habitat for birds, mammals and reptiles, restoring forest ecosystems and creating microclimates. These benefits are important given the current rate of loss of native forest by land clearing, logging and bushfire.

Other nations have already begun planting trees. This includes a number of African countries, Scotland plus countries which are part of the Bonn Challenge. The Bonn Challenge was started in 2011 by the Government of Germany. The Bonn Challenge is a global effort to bring 150 million hectares of the world's deforested and degraded land into restoration by 2020, and 350 million hectares by 2030.
We therefore ask the House to develop policy for funding and implementation of reforestation of unproductive cleared land with native species.
From 6 citizens (EN1228)
Climate Change
Appoint Royal Commission scientifically evaluate Australia's climate energy and policies
We commend and support Alan Kohler in The Australian Sept 21,2019, to evaluate Australia's current climate and energy policies via Royal Commission.

"… (people need to be) confronted with reality … global warming is (not) a matter of religion or ideology (but) rather (of) science … (and whatever they believe) they have nothing to fear from an inquiry."
People only hear activist's opinions on climate change - never empirical evidence.

"This is serious: … much of Australia's prosperity relies on fossil fuel exports but … (we) need a final, believable, public debate where the issue can be tested judicially, (under oath) and agreement reached ... (on a plan) …"

We therefore ask the House to appoint a Royal Commission to evaluate the underlying 'purely theoretical' carbon dioxide theory of global warming. Although based on large computerised models incorporating basic physics models, there is no empirical evidence anyone can point to, suggesting Australia's current climate and energy policies are due diligence and evidence free.

Assurance that quality due diligence is applied to underlying science-based assumptions, data collection, technological developments and evidence based public policies, is essential for an informed free market and body politic to function successfully.
Understanding the relative impact of both natural climate change and man-made climate change will better suggest a plan with clear, achievable timeframes and outcomes.
As warranted by the potential scale of the impact on the nation - as Alan Kohler observed, "… a dispassionate understanding of these science-based problems is therefore required …".
From 1332 citizens (EN1231)
Migration
Reconsideration of protection claims of the Piri family.

This petition draws the attention of the House to the plight of Shamsullah Piri, Zainab Piri, Ryan Diako Piri (4yr) and Liam Diane Piri (2yr), a family of stateless Faili Kurds, previously resident in Ilam, Iran, who arrived in Australia by boat on 08.09.2012 and who have been on a Bridging Visa for the last seven years.
The family recently requested the Minister to intervene in their case, but the Department of Home Affairs found that their circumstances were not within the Ministerial Guidelines.
This petition asks the Parliament to consider the following:
1. Since their protection application was decided, this family's circumstances have changed.
2. Zainab Piri has converted from non-practicing Muslim to Christianity and been baptised in the Baptist church.
3. In Iran, the penalty for converting away from Islam (apostacy) is death.
4. In 2017, Iranian authorities executed more than 500 people.
5. Faili Kurds in Iran are an ethnic minority facing discrimination and persecution, which increases this family's vulnerability.
6. This family has been absent from Iran for more than seven years, which would bring them to the attention of Iranian authorities if they return.

7. In our view, the combination of these factors creates a real chance of this family facing serious harm if returned to Iran, and all of these circumstances have not yet been considered by a decision-maker.
We therefore ask the House to request that the Minister exercise his personal powers to allow this family to have their protection claims re-considered.
From 114 citizens (EN1232)
Crime
Whatever crimes committed by the fire liter courses

If the judges hand down a harder sentence to pyromaniacs, they will be less hesitant to lite fires. Plus, offering counselling for pyromaniacs. By offering counselling to those pyromaniacs who want help. The impact on the pyromaniac over time will become healthier mentally, and emotionally more stable lifestyle. E.I. Not just being charged for lighting the fire, but also for the death the fire has caused, if proven that the fire caused the deaths from the pyromaniac the lite the fire.

We therefore ask the House to change the laws to charge anyone proven to light fire where the fire has kill people, to apply the charge of murder, and any associated crime related to the fire the pyromaniac has lite with a NO PAROLE PERIOD, in any circumstances.
From 1 citizen (EN1233)
Australian Bushfires
Buy 1,000 fire fighting robots

We are in 2020 and there are firefighting robots and technology available to help extinguish fires (eg. Colossus used in the Notre Dame fire in Paris). We urge the Australian government to purchase large amounts of these firefighting robots that can be controlled remotely at a safe distance to support firefighters, help increase their safety and to also reduce fatigue levels.

We therefore ask the House to consider urgently allocating funding for the purchase at least 1,000 firefighting robots to be deployed to any State or Territory fighting bushfires and to train firefighters and community volunteers in using the robots.
From 5 citizens (EN1235)
Australian Bushfires
Honours List for Fire Fighters

From 4 citizens (EN1248)
Cybersafety
Establish regulations and standards for "Smart Devices"/"Internet of Things" (IoT)

The market for "Internet of Things" (IoT) or "Smart Devices" connected to the internet is an unregulated wild west of devices that not only is a risk to consumers whose devices might become outright useless if the manufacturer decides to stop supporting them, the market is also a security nightmare.
Such devices have been known to be rendered useless by their manufacturer when support is ceased, and consumers are rarely able to seek recourse or compensation.

Security analysts have been raising the alarm over such devices having extremely poor security standards, and with little to no market incentive to do better, despite such devices being used to wreak havoc on internet infrastructure (such as the Mirai botnet), and they may be a catalyst in a major disaster in the future that could claim lives, as our world becomes more integrated with the internet. Security vulnerabilities can also breach the privacy of Australians, including hackers spying via cameras integrated with such devices.

We therefore ask the House to work with experts on consumer rights and digital security to formulate regulations, standards and practices to address these issues and protect Australian consumers from devices that can become useless and/or vulnerable to security breaches.

From 2 citizens (EN1250)
Climate Change
Citizens' Assembly for climate and ecological justice

Human activity is resulting in dangerous climate change and ecological damage. We have the tools to solve this problem however business as usual, and politics as usual, will not result in the action required to prevent this future from becoming reality.
We therefore ask the House to create and be led by the decisions of a Citizens' Assembly on Climate and Ecological Justice.
A Citizens' Assembly will empower us, the people, with a fair and democratic way to request the changes required to prevent catastrophic climate change and ecological mass extinction.
The Citizens' Assembly on Climate and Ecological Justice will bring together ordinary people to investigate, discuss and make recommendations on how to respond to the climate emergency.
Similar to jury service, members will be randomly selected from across the country.

The process will be designed to ensure that the Assembly reflects the whole population in terms of characteristics such as gender, age, ethnicity, education level and geography. Assembly members will hear balanced information from experts and those most affected by climate change to inform their discussions and reach consensus on recommendations.

The Assembly shall be run by non-governmental organisations under independent oversight. This is the fairest and most powerful way to cut through party politics. It will empower citizens to work together and take responsibility for our climate and ecological emergency.

From 573 citizens (EN1261)
Migration
Reduce Australia's immigration rate to the 20th century average

In 1998, the ABS issued a Media Release setting out its projections for Australia's population growth by 2051. Since then, population projections have been continuously revised upward as Australia maintains one of the highest net overseas migration rates in the world.

The adverse impacts a high immigration rate has on, amongst other things, biodiversity, employment, housing and productivity has been well documented in the academic literature. Indeed, last year Infrastructure Australia voiced its concerns regarding the immigration rate as a driver of congestion in our cities.

Recent surveys conducted by the ANU and the Lowy Institute demonstrate that there is a concern amongst the Australian public that the current immigration intake is too high. This indicates that there is support amongst the community to wind back the net overseas migration rate to the 20th century average of 70,000 permanent arrivals per year. I would also call for a reduction in the number of temporary arrivals (e.g. student visas, bridging visas,457 visas).
There is an overwhelming body of evidence that Australia is already overpopulated. We need to reduce the immigration rate if we are to maintain a standard of living that we have enjoyed in the past.

We therefore ask the House to reduce the immigration rate through policy/legislation or to hold a plebiscite on the issue so that the majority of Australians can have their say regarding the immigration rate.

From 3 citizens (EN1274)
Parliamentarians' Remuneration
A Radical Review of Federal Politicians' Remuneration

In the spirit of the Australian fair-go, we propose the Parliament of Australia adopts a similar parliamentary system of remuneration as in Sweden, where politicians have no official cars or personal drivers, aides, secretaries, or immunity, their offices are modest, average salaries are approximately double an elementary school teacher's, and they routinely travel by public transport. The Swedish Government provides 2-star accommodation for their politicians. They do not use titles such as "Excellency" but use the same patronyms as their constituents.*
We therefore ask the House to:
1. Cap maximum salary for Australian politicians at $132,000, noting this is almost the median tax-filer's income of $44,527 x 3**
2. Review the use of publicly funded cars and planes, and politicians to use public transport, bicycles, economy class or private vehicles whenever possible.
3. Abolish the use of private secretaries.

4. Conduct an independent examination re the living arrangements of politicians in Canberra, with a view to the cessation of excessive daily allowances, and provision of modest accommodation by Treasury instead.
5. Limit electorate offices and staff numbers to essential requirements only.

6. Investigate politician's spending on 'entertainment' costs such as flowers, alcohol, dinner parties, childcare services and laundry. Indue BASICS cards to be issued; moneys to be reclaimed via Robodebt.
7. Cease using archaic titles such as "Honourable", placing politicians on the same level as other Australian citizens.
*Claudia Wallin: "Sweden The Untold Story"
**Grattan Institute, quoted by James Fernyhough, Money Editor of The New Daily, June 8,2018

Roads

This petition is a request for the installation of Wildlife Detectors on National Highways and roads where there are frequent animal/vehicle incidents around Australia.
The high occurrence of human/wildlife accidents on highways around Australia is a circumstance which is detrimental to both wildlife, and drivers.

Wildlife deaths on our roads are inestimable and can easily be prevented. Wildlife Detectors are effective, easy to install and affordable. From 13 citizens (EN1282)
Blood Donation
Address inequality in Blood Donation requirements and defferal periods.

After the Same-Sex Marriage Plebescite in 2017 and subsequent Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017, many LGBTQIA+ Australians celebrated a landmark shift in the fight for true equality in Australia. However, over two years later, the LGBT+ Australian is not truly equal across society. In particular, the Australian Red Cross refuses blood donations from men who have engaged in sexual acts with other men in the preceding twelve months, or women who have engaged in such acts with men in male-male relations in the same period. Such a deferral does not exist for non-LGBT members of Australian Society. The reasoning for this lays in discriminatory evidence from decades ago and is rooted in the presumption that LGBT men are more liable to carry HIV or other blood-related STD's. However, men such as myself are prohibited from donating blood even if we can prove that our blood is disease-free regardless.

We therefore ask the House to do all it can to leverage the Red Cross to alter its policy on LGBT blood donations. The Australian Red Cross, to truly champion equality in society, ought remove the defferal period required for the LGBT+ community and instead require a blood test from all members of society before donatiing blood, regardless of sexual orientation.

From 74 citizens (EN1285)
Medical Workforce
General Practice Nurses at risk in Tasmania
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

The Morrison Liberal Government has changed to the Monash Modified Model classification system for health services. Consequently, some areas of Tasmania have been reclassified without due recognition of the challenges they face to provide GP services. For example, the small rural town of Lilydale struggles to attract GPs yet has been reclassified to be of equivalent standing to Launceston (MM2).

In addition, from the 1st of January 2020, the Morrison Liberal Government will no longer provide rural loadings to MM2 areas with the result places like Launceston will no longer receive support to employ nurses in GP practices, putting these nursing jobs at risk. Nor will these practices be eligible for the new Workforce Incentive Programs, which will be restricted to MM3-7 areas.

As a regional island state with some of the poorest health outcomes in the nation and made up of largely rural communities struggling to attract and retain doctors, we believe the government should reclassify Tasmanian MM2 areas to MM3 or reinstate eligibility for MM2 areas for Federal Government workforce incentive programs.

We therefore ask the House to request the Morrison Liberal Government to save General Practice nursing jobs by reviewing the MM model's application in Tasmania due to the unique circumstances of our island state and either maintain the incentive payments to General Practice in MM2 Tasmanian areas or reclassify MM2 areas in Tasmania to MM3.

From 1 citizen (EN1329)
Nuclear Waste
Rescind decision to store radioactive waste near Kimba, South Australia.
The Federal Government has not established a need for a national repository for radioactive waste.

Two sources account for 90% of radioactive waste: the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology (ANSTO) facility at Lucas Heights ( 85% is produced for medical isotopes) and 2000 cubic metres of low level waste at Woomera.
Bushfires like those of late 2019 and 2020 could engulf the site.
The Federal Government is overriding South Australian legislation prohibiting radioactive waste sites.
The Federal Government has a track record of failed radioactive cleanups, e.g. Maralinga nuclear test site.

The waste site will not facilitate nuclear medicine. ANSTO's decision to produce medical isotopes using uranium powered nuclear reactors compromises the environment. By comparison, the "light" method of medical isotope production, marketed at the LINAC synchrotron facility in Saskatchewan, Canada is a clean and cheap method with zero radioactive by-product that ANSTO could have adopted.

The Federal Government has stated that there must be broad community support for a radioactive waste site. Having not included the votes of the traditional owners invalidates the vote result. The traditional owners of Muckaty Station in the Northern Territory, whose successful challenge in 2014 in Federal Court to the nomination of a radioactive waste site on their lands, have set a precedent for the Barngarla traditional owners to challenge the decision.

Urge China to immediately end the practice of organ harvesting from all prisoners of conscience and conduct a thorough public education campaign to ensure Australians do not unknowingly participate in forced organ harvesting in China; 3. Deny visas and bar entry to Chinese officials and policemen who are involved in the persecution of Falun Gong.

PETITIONS
Responses
Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (16:27): by leave—I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented to the House.
Education
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your email of 9 September 2019 regarding Education Petition EN0934. In response to the issues raised in the petition I can provide the following advice.

The Foundation to Year 10 Australian Curriculum sets the expectations for what all students should be taught regardless of where they live or their background. Ministers agreed at the December 2019 Education Council meeting to immediately bring forward a review of the curriculum. Ministers noted it is timely to undertake a review, which will commence with mathematics in 2020 alongside conceptual work on science.

The Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) will develop terms of reference for the review, which will be on the agenda at the first Education Council meeting in 2020. There will be extensive consultation, including with professional and key stakeholder groups. The review may present an opportunity for the petitioner to express their thoughts about the content of the curriculum.

While the Australian Government takes a leadership role in matters of national education policy, the delivery of school education is a matter for state and territory government and non-government education authorities. The petitioner may wish to contact their state or territory education minister to discuss their concerns. Contact details are attached.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
