Health Care
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your email of 9 September 2019 regarding petition number: EN0939 asking the Australian Government to consider mandatory cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) training in schools.

The teaching of important first aid skills such as CPR is addressed in the Australian Curriculum (the curriculum) under the Health and Physical Education learning area. For example, in Years 9 and 10 this can include rehearsing CPR and first aid for use in managing situations where the students own or others health, safety or wellbeing may be at short or long term risk. More information on the Australian Curriculum Learning Area: Health and Physical Education is available at www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/f-10-curriculum/health-and-physical-education.

While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, state and territory government and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education programs. The curriculum allows teachers and schools to have considerable flexibility in how they deliver curriculum and recognises they are best able to determine the appropriate approach for their communities.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan
Uluru
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 February 2020 concerning petition EN1135 on the decision to close the climb to Uluru.

As you may be aware, Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park was handed back to its Aboriginal traditional owners (Anangu) on 26 October 1985. The Park is leased to the Director of National Parks and jointly managed by the Uluru-Kata Tjuta Board of Management (the Board).
The Plan stated that the climb will be permanently closed when one of three criteria are met:
the Board, in consultation with the tourism industry, is satisfied that adequate new visitor experiences have been successfully established, or
the proportion of visitors climbing Uluru falls below 20 per cent, or
the cultural and natural experiences on offer are the critical factors when visitors make their decision to visit the park.

The Board undertook more than seven years of consultation, research and debate and was guided by the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park Management Plan 2010-2020 (the Plan) and made the decision to close the climb in November 2017. The Board was provided with evidence the latter two of the three criteria had been fulfilled, and then unanimously agreed (and were obliged under the Management Plan) to close the climb. At the time of the Board's decision, less than 20 per cent of visitors climbed, down from 74 per cent in the 1990s.

The Board is extremely supportive of the tourism industry, seeing future partnerships to keep our Park's living culture strong, as well as providing meaningful jobs and training opportunities for the next generation.
The closure received support from the tourism industry, and visitor numbers remain higher than before the closure was announced in 2017.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, MsLey
Australia Day
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, dated 11 February 2020 , enclosing petition EN1136, which requests that the Government enact a law to prevent any change to Australia Day, the Australian National Flag and the Australian National Anthem. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf as the Minister responsible for national symbols policy.

Australia Day is a day when we can acknowledge actions of the past, celebrate the greatness of Australia and welcome our newest Australians alongside the world's oldest living culture. It's a day to reflect on the past, present and future — to think about where we have been and where we are going as a nation.

It's a day to listen to each other and respect each other's stories and contributions. Australia Day is also a day to celebrate our extraordinary nation, its achievements and, most of all, its people. It celebrates our diverse background and the extraordinary achievements that have made Australia a successful multicultural society.
On occasion suggestions are made to change Australia Day from 26 January to another date.

It is the Prime Minister's view that Australia Day should continue to be celebrated on January 26 as our premier national day. Australia Day on 26 January is a day for all Australians, regardless of background.

The Australian National Flag is Australia's foremost national symbol. It was first flown in 1901 and has become an expression of Australian identity and pride. The Flags Act 1953 requires a poll of all Australians before the design of the Australian National Flag can be changed.

The Australian National Anthem is widely accepted by Australians. The words and tune of the Australian National Anthem were proclaimed by the Governor-General of Australia on 19 April 1984, after extensive surveys of national opinion, starting in the 1970s.
The Government has no plans to change these important national symbols. Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Morton
Adani Carmichael Mine
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 February 2020 concerning petition EN1143 about the approval of Adani's Carmichael Coal Mine and Rail Project (EPBC 2010-5736).

The role of the Australian Government in relation to the Project is as an environmental regulator for matters of national environmental significance as defined in the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). In deciding to approve the Project and what conditions to impose, the then Minister for the Environment, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, considered the impacts of the proposed action on matters protected by the EPBC Act and other economic and social matters.

Protecting precious water resources from the impacts of large coal mines is a priority for the Australian Government. The information used to assess the Project's impacts on water was provided by the public, environmental groups and the Independent Expert Scientific Committee on Coal Seam Gas and Large Coal Mining Development (IESC). Adani are required to prepare comprehensive groundwater management plans and strategies and undertake monitoring to detect any changes to groundwater early. They must also implement measures to return 3,650 million litres per year to the Great Artesian Basin to replace water used during mining.

Australia addresses the emissions arising from the use of coal through a range of measures to deal with climate change. At the international level, Australia is a party to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Paris Agreement. Australia also has a comprehensive set of policies to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions, including through the Emissions Reduction Fund, Safeguard Mechanism, Renewable Energy Target, and National Energy Productivity Plan. The global nature of emissions means that broader approaches are preferred, rather than focussing on individual projects.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, MsLey
Education: Indigenous Studies
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your email of 9 September 2019 regarding an Education Petition asking that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies be made mandatory in the Australian Curriculum (Petition No: EN0987).

The Australian Government believes it is critical that all school students should have the opportunity to learn about our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and their history. The nationally-agreed Foundation to Year 10 Australian Curriculum includes opportunities for all Australians to learn about these topics.
The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Histories and Cultures Cross-curriculum Priority addresses two distinct needs:

that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students are able to see themselves, their identities and their cultures reflected in the curriculum of each of the learning areas to fully participate in the curriculum and build their self-esteem; and
to enable all students to engage in reconciliation, respect and recognition of the world's oldest continuous living cultures.

In Year 3 Humanities and Social Sciences, students can explore the importance of country and place to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. By the end of Year 5 Humanities and Social Sciences, students develop knowledge of how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities altered the environment and sustained ways of living through their methods of land and resource management. In Years 9 and 10 History, students learn about the impact of European contact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island peoples and their struggle to gain civil rights. In addition, a Framework for Aboriginal Languages and Torres Strait Islander Languages (the Framework) is also part of the Foundation to Year 10 Language learning area. It provides a way forward for schools in Australia to support the teaching and learning of these languages.

While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, state and territory government and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education programs. The Australian Curriculum allows teachers and schools to have considerable flexibility in how they deliver the curriculum and recognises they are best able to determine the appropriate approach for their communities.
Thank you for raising this important matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan
Hong Kong
Dear Ms Elliot

Thank you for your correspondence of 25 November 2019 concerning petition EN1067 regarding access to Australia's visa programs by British Overseas Nationals resident in Hong Kong. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

British Overseas Nationals are treated equally in Australia's Migration and Citizenship Program. The program is based on a universal, non-discriminatory visa system which focuses on the contribution a person can make to Australia, rather than their ethnicity, gender, political or religious beliefs.
Australia enjoys high levels of social cohesion and broad public support for its Migration Programs. This is in part based around confidence in well-managed non-discriminatory migration.
Australia's Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) usually include commitments on the movement of natural persons, but these do not provide for unrestricted movement and work rights between the Parties.

FTA commitments build on existing World Trade Organization temporary entry commitments, which focus on facilitating temporary entry for professionals and skilled workers. Such provisions support broader FTA commitments on trade in services and investment.

Negotiations with the United Kingdom (UK) will seek outcomes that also focus on temporary entry for these types of skilled workers. These should be ambitious outcomes that support services exports to and investments in the UK.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Internet Content
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter dated 25 November 2019, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN1071 ­ restrictions of free adult movies online.

The Morrison Government recognises that access to sexually explicit material online is an issue of concern for many Australians, and that exposure to inappropriate content can have negative impacts on children.

In the context of the 2019 election, the Government committed to making available to parents and carers the option of a filtered internet service that, at a minimum, blocks access to websites identified by the eSafety Commissioner. This commitment is being progressed as part of a broader program of reform of Australia's regulatory framework for online services, outlined in more detail below.

The Online Content Scheme currently regulates prohibited and potential prohibited online content based on the National Classification Scheme. Content is assessed on the basis of a public complaint to the eSafety Commissioner. If the Commissioner finds content hosted in Australia to be prohibited content, the Commissioner will direct the content provider to remove or prevent access to the content. For prohibited content hosted overseas, the URL to the material is added to the Commissioner's prohibited URLs list, which is distributed to PC filter vendors accredited under an Industry Code of Practice. This is more commonly known as the 'family friend filter' (or FFF) scheme.

The prohibition of content, including child abuse images, pornography and terrorist-related material, is backed by strong sanctions for non-compliance, including criminal penalties for serious offences.

span.span: Proposal to modernise the Online Content Scheme

p.span: On 11 December 2019, I announced a series of proposed reforms to Australia's online safety regulatory framework. These reforms seek to strengthen our current arrangements and modernise aspects of our framework that are no longer effective in a contemporary digital media environment.

The Government's proposal for a revised Online Content Scheme would enhance the eSafety Commissioner's ability to address illegal and harmful content online by expanding the take-down notice scheme. In addition, online service providers would be required to meet obligations under updated industry code requirements. This would include a requirement to use the best available technology to prevent children's access to harmful and age-inappropriate content such as pornography.

Service providers would also be expected to make available to consumers information relating to opt-in tools and services that inform users about the steps they can take to manage their own online safety. The Government expects that improvements in these tools and services, and significant software upgrades, should also be communicated regularly in order to promote good online safety habits beyond the point-of-purchase.
More information on the proposals to reform Australia's online safety legislation is available at www.communications.gov.au/have-your-say/consultation-new-online-safety-act.

In addition to these initiatives by Government, a number of mobile phone providers also offer filtering solutions for mobile devices. For example, parental controls are available on most devices including computers, tablets and smartphones. These tools help parents monitor and limit what children do online. Most of these tools can block children from accessing specific sites and are able to filter different kinds of content, including pornography.
Web browsers also have a range of parental controls which parents and carers can set to allow children to more safely explore the internet.

There are also child-friendly search engines available. These search engines provide child friendly content by screening search results for inappropriate sites and materials. In addition to this, most search engines have safe settings available to filter out inappropriate, explicit and adult content from search results.
Further information on all of these tools can be found on the eSafety Commissioner's website at www.esafety.gov.au/parents/skills-advice/taming-technology.

The eSafety Commissioner also helps to equip Australian families with the skills to navigate safety online. eSafety has a range of practical advice for parents and carers about online pornography including setting house rules, using parental controls, having age-appropriate discussions and the importance of respectful relationships. There is also other information available to support parents such as information about 'sexting', cyberbullying and managing time spent online. These resources can be accessed through the eSafety Commissioner's website at www.esafety.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing the concerns in this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Federal Independent Commission Against Corruption
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 25 November 2019 regarding petition EN1088, which seeks the establishment of a federal independent commission against corruption. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.
The Australian Government is firmly committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible to maximise public confidence in our national institutions.
That is why on 13 December 2018 the Government announced that it would establish a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) to enhance national integrity arrangements across the federal public sector.

The CIC will be an independent statutory agency, led by a commissioner and two deputy commissioners. It will include a public sector integrity division and law enforcement integrity division, ensuring targeted attention to corruption and fraud across the entirety of the public sector.

Through the CIC, the Government will target serious criminal corruption that presents a threat to good public administration. It will not duplicate the roles of existing bodies, but instead will provide expert capability to investigate allegations of serious criminal corruption within the public sector. Existing integrity agencies will be able to refer matters to the CIC, and vice versa.

Similarly, existing mechanisms for dealing with allegations about misconduct that falls short of the criminal standard, such as arrangements for handling allegations that a parliamentarian has engaged in workplace bullying or harassment, or misused parliamentary entitlements, will remain.

The Government has been consulting widely to ensure that the model for the new Commission strengthens federal integrity arrangements without compromising fundamental principles of our criminal justice system.

Further information on the Government's proposed model for the new Commission is available on the Attorney-General's Department website, at the following address: https://www.ag.gov.au/Consultations/Pages/commonwealth-integrity-commission.aspx.
The Government is currently in the process of finalising draft legislation to establish the CIC, which will soon be released for public consultation.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 25 November 2019 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning the petition seeking a tax exemption for breast feeding items (EN1099). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

Firstly, I would like to acknowledge the concerns of the petitioners about the costs associated with breastfeeding and the return to work, and that breastfeeding equipment is important for many families. There is no suggestion that because something is subject to GST it is considered to be unnecessary or unimportant. However, the GST operates most efficiently when applied to as broad a range of goods and services as possible including those that are essential. Every additional exemption adds to the complexity of the GST system and increases the compliance costs of taxpayers, which are passed on to consumers. Additional exemptions would create new anomalies and lead to calls for further exemptions.

The GST is levied by the Australian Government on behalf of the states and territories. The revenue from the GST goes to the states and territories and provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community, such as health and education. Extending the range of GST-free goods and services would reduce the revenue of the state and territory governments, undermining their ability to provide essential services.
Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and Commonwealth legislation, any change to the base of the GST requires the unanimous agreement of the states and territories.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
National Integrity Commission
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 November 2019 regarding Petition EN1112 about federal anti-corruption arrangements. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The petitioners request that the Parliament immediately pass the Australian Greens' National Integrity Commission Bill 2018 (the NIC Bill) with amendments to include a Parliamentary code of ethics or integrity for those nominated for election, or currently serving as a member or Senator.
The Australian Government is firmly committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible to maximise public confidence in our national institutions.
That is why on 13 December 2018 the Government announced that it would establish a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) to enhance national integrity arrangements across the federal public sector.

The CIC will be an independent statutory agency, led by a commissioner and two deputy commissioners. It will include a public sector integrity division and law enforcement integrity division, ensuring targeted attention to corruption and fraud across the entirety of the public sector.

Through the CIC, the Government will target serious criminal corruption that presents a threat to good public administration. It will not duplicate the roles of existing bodies, but instead will provide expert capability to investigate allegations of serious criminal corruption within the public sector. Existing integrity agencies will be able to refer matters to the CIC, and vice versa.

Similarly, existing mechanisms for dealing with allegations about misconduct that falls short of the criminal standard, such as arrangements for handling allegations that a parliamentarian has engaged in workplace bullying or harassment, or misused parliamentary entitlements, will remain.

The Government has been consulting widely to ensure that the model for the new Commission strengthens federal integrity arrangements without compromising fundamental principles of our criminal justice system.
The Government does not support the model for an integrity commission set out in the Greens' NIC Bill. There are a number of issues with the Greens' proposal, including:
the Bill could lead to duplication or overlap with existing integrity agencies, such as the Australian Public Service Commission or the Ombudsman
the scope of what can constitute corrupt conduct is overly broad and means that very serious coercive powers could be applied to relatively minor disciplinary matters, and
The Bill captures indirect conduct that may impair confidence or functions of public officials, meaning a person may be subject to a finding of corruption for conduct they did not intend.

These deficiencies will be addressed by the draft legislation to implement the CIC, which the Government is in the process of finalising. This will form the basis of further public consultation before the CIC model is finalised.

Further information on the Government's proposed model for the new Commission is available on the Attorney General's Department website, at the following address: https://www.ag.gov.au/Consultations/Pages/commonwealth-integrity-commission.aspx.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter
Prime Minister
Dear Ms Elliot
Thank you for the Committee's letter to me of 11 February 2020 in my capacity as Leader of the House regarding a petition concerning Members' qualifications (petition number EN1145).

The House of Representatives Standing Orders provide for a detailed process to refer Members of the House of Representatives to the Court of Disputed Returns in relation to questions of a Member's qualification.

Specifically, no Member may move a motion to refer any question to the Court of Disputed Returns under s 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Cth) unless the Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests has considered whether the matter be so referred and reported to the House of Representatives.
In relation to individual Member's qualifications, all Members provide a statement which is published on the Parliament website at
https://www.aph.gov.au/Senators_and_Members/Members/Qualifications which may be of interest to the petitioners.
I trust this information is of interest to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Leader of the House, Mr Porter
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 February 2020 concerning Petition EN1166 on all-inclusive pricing.

The Australian Government is sympathetic to the concerns raised by the petitioners. While the interest rates and fees financial institutions charge are commercial decisions for them, the Government considers it is important that the pricing practices of Australia's financial institutions are transparent and understood by consumers. To this end, both the Corporations Act 2001 and the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009 impose a range of obligations on banks to ensure consumers are aware of the fees charged for the financial products and services they use.

Additionally, if a business chooses to impose a surcharge on its customers for making a payment using a credit, debit, or prepaid card, there is an expectation that the level of surcharge must not be excessive. On 25 February 2016 the Competition and Consumer Amendment (Payment Surcharges) Act 2016 inserted a new part into the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 banning excessive payment surcharges and providing new powers to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Climate Change
Dear Committee
Thank you for your letter of 1 I February 2020 concerning petition number EN1177, regarding helping Australians respond to climate change.

Australia is well positioned to meet the challenge of climate change. Australia has mature financial, welfare and regulatory systems, well-governed institutions, and internationally recognised scientific expertise.

The Australian Government has an extensive agenda in climate resilience and adaptation, backed by billions of dollars of investments. Examples include an initial $2 billion allocation for the Bushfire Recovery Agency to support communities affected by the recent bushfires build back better, and $3.9 billion for the Emergency Response Fund to support disaster-affected communities to be more prepared for and resilient to future natural disasters.

The Government has also committed $5 billion for the Future Drought Fund to support Australian communities prepare for the effects of inevitable future drought, and $3.5 billion through the National Water Grid Authority to build water infrastructure that will strengthen drought resilience. These are practical measures that will prepare Australia for the future.

The Government's 2015 National Climate Resilience and Adaptation Strategy outlines a coordinated whole of-society approach. The Strategy recognises that many resilience and adaptation activities, such as land-use planning, are most effective when addressed at the local or regional level. Businesses, households and communities also have important roles in building resilience.

More information on the National Climate Resilience and Adaptation Strategy is available on the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment website at: environment.gov.au/climate-change/adaptation/strategy.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter dated 11 February 2020 regarding a petition for an emergency joint parliamentary sitting on the recent bushfires and climate change.

I will discuss the recent bushfires, natural disaster arrangements and resilience measures with the heads of the states and territories at the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) in March 2020. In the face of hotter, drier summers, I am focussed on how we can work together to ensure Australia's assets are built to last, built to resist and built to survive our changing climate.

To ensure our efforts are informed by science, I have asked the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to report on practical measures for Australian governments to improve Australia's climate and disaster resilience. The Chief Executive of the CSIRO, Dr Larry Marshall, will present a preliminary report at the March COAG meeting. CSIRO will work in close partnership with an expert advisory panel chaired by the Chief Scientist, Dr Alan Finkel. The expert advisory panel will include experts in climate, weather, bushfire and natural disaster science as well as experts with emergency services and infrastructure experience and traditional indigenous knowledge. You can find the terms of reference for the CSIRO report at www.csiro.au/en/News/News-releases/2020/CSIRO-to-support-nations-bushfire-rebuild.

Australia is taking strong climate action as part of a coordinated global effort. We are committed to the Paris Agreement and have a proud history of meeting and beating our international climate change commitments — we are on track to beat our 2020 target by 411 million tonnes.

Our Paris Target, reducing emissions by 26 to 28 per cent on 2005 levels by 2030, is a responsible one that makes a significant contribution to global climate action. It represents a halving of emissions per person in Australia, or a two-thirds reduction in emissions per unit of GDP. This is no mean feat, given Australia is in its 29th year of uninterrupted economic growth, while emissions per person are at their lowest levels in 29 years.
The Australian Government has a suite of practical policies in place to meet our emissions reduction targets while maintaining a strong and prosperous economy.

At the centre of our policies is the $3.5 billion Climate Solutions Package, including a new $2 billion Climate Solutions Fund. This builds on our previous $2.55 billion Emissions Reductions Fund and will help businesses, communities and landholders to reduce emissions. So far we have secured more than 190 million tonnes of emissions reductions, of which over 80 per cent will be delivered by the agricultural and land sectors. The Fund supports a range of practical projects, including capturing methane from landfill and storing carbon in forests and soils.

Australia is also on track for around one third of our electricity needs to be met by renewables in the early 2020s. Right now, an unprecedented wave of clean energy investment is underway in Australia and new records are being set. We have the world's highest uptake of rooftop solar — nearly one in four homes have solar on their roofs.

To support the transition to renewable energy, the Government is investing in the energy storage and infrastructure of the future. This includes a $1.38 billion equity investment in the Snowy 2.0 project, which will be the biggest battery in the Southern Hemisphere.

I am proud to say Australia is also a world leader in renewable energy technologies. In 2019, Australia's investment (per person) in renewable energy was greater than the United States, Japan or the United Kingdom, and more than triple the per capita investment of countries like Germany, China, France and Denmark. The Clean Energy Finance Corporation, the world's most successful green bank, has mobilised over $20 billion in new investments in our economy.

Our resources are supporting the transition to lower emissions around the world. We are among the world's largest exporters of Liquefied Natural Gas and hold among the largest reserves of lithium and cobalt for batteries.

Looking ahead, we are developing a National Electric Vehicle Strategy to ensure a planned and managed transition to new vehicle technology. We are investigating cleaner fuels for the future and will deliver a National Hydrogen Strategy by the end of the year. By 2020 we will also develop a long-term strategy to reduce emissions, like other parties to the Paris Agreement.
Yours sincerely
from the Prime Minister, Mr Morrison
Environment
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 February 2020 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding Petition Number EN1183 — Managing waste by removing plastic packaging for food products.
In 2018, Australia's environment ministers agreed to the ambitious target of making
100 per cent of Australian packaging reusable, recyclable or compostable by 2025 or earlier.

To help meet this target the Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation (APCO), in consultation with industry and government, established the 2025 National Packaging Targets to create a new sustainable pathway for the way we manage packaging in Australia:
70 per cent of Australia's plastic packaging recycled or composted;
30 per cent average recycled content across all packaging, and
phasing out problematic and unnecessary single-use plastic packaging through design, innovation or introduction of alternatives.
To drive the delivery of the 2025 National Packaging Targets, APCO and its members, supported by government, are delivering an extensive program of work.

APCO industry members have committed to the design, manufacture and use of packaging that will ensure recyclable packaging. The Australasian Recycling Label is an important tool for increasing the volume of plastic packaging being recycled. The labelling system was developed by Planet Ark, PREP Design and APCO to help consumers better understand how to recycle packaging.

APCO is also working with the Queensland Department of Environment and Science (DES) and the National Retail Association to develop a voluntary code of practice to phase out the use of heavier, single-use plastic shopping bags.

APCO recently published a list of priority problematic and unnecessary single-use plastic packaging for phase-out, and a list of packaging for further investigation that were developed following extensive consultation with industry and government. The list supports Target 5 (and Action 5.4) of the National Waste Policy Action Plan and the National Packaging Targets.
Environment ministers agreed in November 2019 to write to APCO to set out their expectations on new packaging targets, including plastic packaging.
Thank you again for bringing the Committee's concerns regarding plastic packaging to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 February 2020 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning petition number PN0456. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Australian Government considers the safety of deposits and the financial system of significant importance. That is why the Government passed the Financial Sector Legislation Amendment (Crisis Resolution Powers and Other Measures) Act 2018 (the Act), which strengthens the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's (APRA) crisis management toolkit in relation to banks and insurers. This Act does not implement any sort of policy that would allow the seizure of deposits in times of financial instability. Details can be found at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/Bills_Search_Results/Result?bId=r5989.
The Act enhances APRA's crisis management powers by providing APRA with:
clear powers to set requirements on resolution planning and to ensure banks and insurers are better prepared for a crisis; and
an expanded set of crisis resolution powers that equip APRA to act decisively to facilitate the orderly resolution of a distressed bank or insurer.

To reduce the risk of banking crises, the Government has also endorsed APRA setting "unquestionably strong" capital requirements. These requirements contemplate banks and insurers issuing hybrid securities, which can be converted into ordinary shares or written off to absorb losses. To ensure that capital instruments such as hybrid securities do function as intended, the above legislation provides certainty that capital instruments can be converted or written off as provided for in APRA's prudential standards.

The intention of the definition of 'conversion and write-off provisions' is to appropriately 'future-proof the legislation by referring not only to existing forms of capital (such as All and T2 capital) but to other instruments that could be the subject of such provisions under APRA's capital framework in the future. This reflects that prudential requirements can change over time and the instruments that are recognised as capital under APRA's prudential standards could be referred to differently in the future. However, this would not extend to deposits as these are decisively outside the capital framework.

In addition to this legislation, depositors' claims are explicitly protected by the Banking Act 1959. In the unlikely event of a bank failure, depositors have priority claim on the assets of a failed authorised deposit-taking institution (ADI) ahead of other unsecured creditors. Depositors are also protected by the Financial Claims Scheme, which guarantees deposits up to a cap of $250,000 per person, per ADI.
ADIs are also intensively supervised by APRA. APRA's statutory objectives include both protecting the interests of depositors and promoting financial system stability in Australia.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COMMITTEES
Regional Australia Select Committee
Report

Mr DRUM (Nicholls—Chief Nationals Whip) (16:27): On behalf of the select committee and the chair, Mr Tony Pasin, I present the committee's interim report on regional Australia, together with the minutes of the proceedings.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr DRUM: by leave—I would like to acknowledge that, on 25 July 2019, the Assistant Minister for Children and Families, the Hon. Michelle Landry MP, asked the committee to inquire into and report on matters affecting regional Australia. The committee has conducted three site inspections and three community roundtable discussions in George Town, Launceston and Hobart in Tasmania. Due to the uncertainty regarding the current coronavirus pandemic, the committee has been unable to consider a fulsome interim report and intends to conduct further public hearings and site inspections when appropriate. The committee also understands that challenges stemming from the 2019-20 bushfires have impacted on the ability of some organisations and individuals to participate in the committee's work. The committee intends to seek an extension of time to report fully. Thank you on behalf of the chair, Mr Tony Pasin.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Andrews ): I thank the member for Nicholls for that interim report on an important matter of regional affairs.

Electric Vehicles
(Question No. 291)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, in writing, on 05 February 2020:

Further to the answer to question in writing No. 252—in the response to part (2) of the question, the Minister indicates that the Adelaide Hills is an anticipated location for an electrical vehicle charging site to be delivered by Evie (the Adelaide Hills region being within the electoral division of Mayo); however, in part (1) of the question, the Minister states that 'The Australian Renewable Energy Agency has been advised by Evie that there are no sites confirmed for the electoral division of Mayo as part of this deployment plan': does the Minister mean that there is a single site anticipated to be located within Mayo but that exact site has yet to be confirmed, or does the Minister mean that whether a site will be located within the Adelaide Hills or not has yet to be confirmed.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Neither the Australian Government nor ARENA have input into Evie's determination of individual electrical vehicle charging locations.Evie is still in the process of confirming a site in the near vicinity of Adelaide as part of its project. ARENA understands Evie's current preference is to find a site in Adelaide Hills, however this has not yet been finalised.
Migration
(Question No. 293)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 5 February 2020:

span.span: 1.What is the Government's understanding of the reasons for delays in Venezuelan citizens being able to renew their passports and identity documents.

2.Is it correct that: (a) the Interim President Juan Guaido signed a decree extending the validity of all Venezuelan passports for an additional five years past their expiration date; and (b) countries including the United States, Canada, France, Spain, Mexico and Chile recognise this decree and the extension of passports for entering those countries and for general consular purposes.
3.Will the Government recognise this decree and the extension of the validity of Venezuelan passports
for some or all Australian Government purposes; if so, when and how will this recognition operate; if not, why not.

p.span: Mr Tudge: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

This is not a matter for the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs. This question should be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne.
Recycling
(Question No. 295)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 6 February 2020:
In respect of Contract Notice CN3656413 published on AusTender on 30 January 2020:
1. What market economic analysis is to be conducted by the Centre for International Economics.
2. Is the analysis relevant to any government policies or programs; if so, what are those policies or programs.
3. What methodologies will be used for this analysis.
4. Do the methodologies include economic modelling; if so: (a) what type of modelling is to be employed; (b) what model will be used; and (c) what policy scenarios will be examined in this modelling.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
1. The analysis evaluated the costs and benefits of implementing the Council of Australian Governments' announcement to ban the exports of waste plastic, paper, tyres and glass.
2. Yes. The Council of Australian Governments' waste export ban.
3. Cost benefit analysis.
4. Yes.
(a) Cost benefit analysis.
(b) Partial equilibrium model with excel based cost benefit analysis.
(c) Modelling assessed four alternate scenarios, relative to the base case to inform implementation of the Council of Australian Governments' waste export ban.
1. The base case included the existing domestic policy settings. It did not include the introduction of export bans.
2. Scenario 1 introduced the export ban as defined by Environment Ministers in November 2019.
3. Scenario 2 was a variant on Scenario 1, with an exemption for clean paper and cardboard.
4. Scenario 3 was a variant on Scenario 1, with an exemption for whole tyres for retreading.
5. Scenario 4 was a variant on Scenario 1, which included an exemption for whole tyres for retreading and an exemption for clean paper and cardboard.

subdebateinfo.title: Tuggerah Lakes Estuary Management Plan (Question No. 313)

p.span: Tuggerah Lakes Estuary Management Plan
(Question No. 313)
Ms McBride asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 25 February 2020:
In respect of my letter, dated 13 February 2020, concerning the 2019 federal election commitment of up to $4.7 million for the Tuggerah Lakes under the Environment Restoration Fund:
1. What is the exact amount of funding that the Central Coast Council is to receive.
2. Is it a fact that nine months after the election, this funding has not yet been received by the Central Coast Council.
3. When will these funds be received given the urgency following the recent floods.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. The Central Coast Council is to receive $4.7 million to undertake projects in support of the implementation of the Tuggerah Lakes Estuary Management Plan. Works will include: wetland and threatened species habitat conservation, streambank and catchment improvements, bushland and saltmarsh rehabilitation, and foreshore and water quality improvements throughout the estuary catchment.

2. The Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources' Business Grants Hub issued the Central Coast Council with a funding agreement at the beginning of March 2020 and it is expected that the Business Grants Hub will execute the funding agreement once it has been agreed with the Council.
3. Once a funding agreement has been executed, the Central Coast Council will receive funding in accordance agreed milestone payments listed in the funding agreement.

subdebateinfo.title: East Antarctic Marine Protected Area (Question No. 327)

p.span: East Antarctic Marine Protected Area
(Question No. 327)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Environment in writing, on 05 March 2020:

1. Has the proposal for the East Antarctic Marine Protected Area (EAMPA) changed since it was first tabled by Australia, France and the European Union in 2012; if so: (a) in what way has it changed; and (b) have the changes reduced the biodiversity outcomes that will come from the park.

2. What is the Australian Antarctic Division doing this year to give the confirmation of the EAMPA its best chance at this year's Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) meeting in October in Hobart.

3. What will the Environment and Foreign Affairs Ministers and the Prime Minister be doing at a high level with other key CCAMLR signatories, in particular China, to see the EAMPA get over the line this year at CCAMLR.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Yes. The EAMPA co-proponents (Australia and the European Union and its Member States) have revised the proposal a number of times since it was first tabled at CCAMLR in 2012. These changes have been made in response to feedback from various CCAMLR members, with a view to obtaining the necessary consensus for the proposal to be adopted.
Specific changes to the proposal include:
The number of areas proposed for protection by the EAMPA has gone from 7 to 3 with the size of the EAMPA being reduced from approximately 1.9 million square kilometres to 1 million square kilometres.
Clarification on where different fishing activities can occur.
The inclusion of a krill no-take zone to assist with monitoring important environmental changes in this area.
Enhanced protection of key shelf ecosystems.

Most recently, in 2019, a different approach was taken to the text of the proposal such that it more closely resembled the language and document structure of the Ross Sea region MPA adopted by CCAMLR in 2016.

The changes made to the EAMPA proposal have been made in response to feedback from various CCAMLR members, with a view to obtaining the necessary consensus for the proposal to be adopted. The fundamental principles of the EAMPA proposal have not changed: representation of Southern Ocean biodiversity, enabling multiple-use of areas while achieving conservation, adaptively managing the areas as new information comes to light, and maintenance of scientific reference areas to support ecosystem-based management.

The Australian Antarctic Division of the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment, continues to work with other Australian government agencies, as well as the European Union and its Member States, on the best strategy for the successful adoption of the proposal. The strategy leading up to the meeting in October 2020 is currently being considered.

Advocacy for the EAMPA proposal is currently under active consideration, noting that opportunities for face to face advocacy are fast reducing as international meetings are cancelled and travel restrictions are put in place in response to COVID-19.
Human Rights
(Question No. 333)
Mr Leeser asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, in writing, on 05 March 2020 :

Since 4 January 2012 when the Human Rights Parliamentary Scrutiny Act 2011 commenced:(1) How many officers in your department have worked on human rights compatibility statements.(2) How many human rights compatibility statements have been issued.(3) What is the APS level of staff who have worked on these statements and what is the salary range of each of those levels.(4) Approximately how many hours of staff time has been spent preparing compatibility statements and responding to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights.(5) What is the estimated cost to your department of producing compatibility statements, over the period January 2012 to present.(6) What is the estimated annual cost of producing human rights compatibility statements.(7) On how many occasions has the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights sought a response from your department about the human rights compatibility statements prepared by your department.(8) On how many occasions has this resulted in changes to the legislation presented by your department, and can details be provided of any changes that have been made.
Mr Frydenberg: The Minister for Finance has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

The Department of Finance complies with all requirements of the Human Rights Parliamentary Scrutiny Act 2011, including the preparation of human rights compatibility statements for all new legislation. The level of the APS officers involved, the amount of time spent on each statement and the estimated cost of preparing the statements will vary depending on the legislation to which it relates. This information is not readily available and to answer the individual questions would require an unreasonable diversion of resources.
